maml:description.maml:para: Adds an ODBC DSN.
The Add-OdbcDsn cmdlet adds an Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) data source name (DSN) to the computer. You can specify the properties of the DSN by using the SetPropertyValue parameter.
Do not use the Set-OdbcDsn cmdlet to add a new DSN.

For more information about ODBC, data source names, and drivers, see Microsoft Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms710252.aspx), [Data Sources](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms711688.aspx), and [Drivers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms715383.aspx)on the Microsoft Developer Network.
Specifies the name of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet creates a DSN that has the name that this parameter specifies.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of a driver. This cmdlet assigns the new ODBC DSN to the driver that this parameter specifies.
Specifies the type of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet adds a DSN of the type that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- User
- System
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet adds an ODBC DSN that belongs to the platform that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote Common Information Model (CIM) session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.
Specifies an array of property values. This cmdlet specifies these property values for the ODBC DSN. Specify an array of strings of the form <key>=<value>.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of a driver. This cmdlet assigns the new ODBC DSN to the driver that this parameter specifies.
Specifies the type of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet adds a DSN of the type that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- User
- System
Specifies the name of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet creates a DSN that has the name that this parameter specifies.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet adds an ODBC DSN that belongs to the platform that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote Common Information Model (CIM) session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.
Specifies an array of property values. This cmdlet specifies these property values for the ODBC DSN. Specify an array of strings of the form <key>=<value>.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: ------------ Example 1: Add a 32-bit ODBC User DSN ------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a 32-bit ODBC User DSN named MyPayroll that uses the specified 32-bit driver with the specified properties.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 2: Add an ODBC System DSN --------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-OdbcDsn -Name "MyPayroll" -DriverName "SQL Server Native Client 10.0" -DsnType "System" -SetPropertyValue @("Server=MyServer", "Trusted_Connection=Yes", "Database=Payroll")

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the ODBC System DSNs named MyPayroll that use SQL Server Native Client 10.0 with the specified DSN properties. Because the command does not include the Platform parameter, the platform architecture is the default, native platform.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 3: Add and store an ODBC System DSN ---------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $NewDsn = Add-OdbcDsn -Name "MyPayroll" -DriverName "SQL Server Native Client 10.0" -DsnType "System" -SetPropertyValue @("Server=MyServer", "Trusted_Connection=Yes", "Database=Payroll") -PassThru

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the ODBC System DSNs named MyPayroll that use SQL Server Native Client 10.0 with the specified DSN properties, and then stores the results in the $NewDsn variable. The command includes the PassThru parameter. Without PassThru , the cmdlet does not return anything.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 4: Migrates DSNs to a newer version of a driver ---
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $DsnArray = Get-OdbcDsn -DriverName 'SQL Server Native Client 10.0' PS C:\> ForEach ($Dsn in $ DsnArr) { Remove-OdbcDsn -InputObject $Dsn # You can change the property array as well, # if DSN attributes have been changed in the new driver version
PS C:\> Add-OdbcDsn -Name $Dsn.Name -DsnType $Dsn.DsnType -Platform $Dsn.Platform -DriverName 'SQL Server Native Client 12.0' -SetPropertyValue $Dsn.PropertyValue }

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets ODBC data source names by using the Get-OdbcDsn cmdlet, and then stores them in the $DsnArray variable.

The second command uses the ForEach Windows PowerShell keyword to step through each member of $DsnArray. For each member, the command uses the current cmdlet to migrate DSNs using the SQL Server Native Client 10.0 driver to a newer version of that driver. This command works for the SQL Server Native Client ODBC driver.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets ODBC DSNs.

The Get-OdbcDsn cmdlet gets Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) data source names (DSNs) from the computer. You can specify values for the Name , DsnType , Platform , and DriverName parameters. If you do not specify Name or DriverName , the cmdlet gets all DSN names and all driver names respectively. If you do not specify any parameter, the cmdlet gets all ODBC DSNs from the computer.

For more information about ODBC, data source names, and drivers, see Microsoft Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms710252.aspx), [Data Sources](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms711688.aspx), and [Drivers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms715383.aspx)on the Microsoft Developer Network.
Specifies the name of an ODBC DSN. You can use wildcard characters to specify more than one ODBC DSN. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet returns all ODBC DSNs.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of a driver. This cmdlet gets ODBC DSNs that use the specified ODBC driver. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet gets all ODBC DSNs.
Specifies the type of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet gets DSNs of the type that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- User
- System
- All
The default value is All.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet gets the ODBC DSN that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All
The default value is All. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of a driver. This cmdlet gets ODBC DSNs that use the specified ODBC driver. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet gets all ODBC DSNs.
Specifies the type of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet gets DSNs of the type that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- User
- System
- All
The default value is All.
Specifies the name of an ODBC DSN. You can use wildcard characters to specify more than one ODBC DSN. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet returns all ODBC DSNs.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet gets the ODBC DSN that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All
The default value is All. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all ODBC User DSNs and System DSNs that use 32-bit or 64-bit ODBC drivers.

command:example.maml:title: ----------- Example 2: Get ODBC System DSNs by name -----------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the ODBC System DSNs named MyPayroll stored in the 32-bit registry location.

command:example.maml:title: -- Example 3: Get ODBC DSNs with names that contain a string --

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all ODBC User DSNs and System DSNs with names that contain the string Payroll. The DSNs are stored in the native hive of the registry location.

command:example.maml:title: ---- Example 4: Get all ODBC User DSNs for specified driver ----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all ODBC User DSNs that use a driver that has the specified name, and then stores those DSN in the $DsnArray variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes ODBC DSNs.
The Remove-OdbcDsn cmdlet removes Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) data source names (DSNs) from the computer.

For more information about ODBC, data source names, and drivers, see Microsoft Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms710252.aspx), [Data Sources](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms711688.aspx), and [Drivers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms715383.aspx)on the Microsoft Developer Network.
Specifies the name of an ODBC DSNs. You can use wildcard characters to specify more than one name. This cmdlet removes the DSNs that the names specify.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the name of a driver. This cmdlet removes the ODBC DSN that uses the driver that this parameter specifies. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet removes DSNs for all drivers.
Specifies the type of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet removes DSNs of the type that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- User
- System
- All
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet removes the ODBC DSNs that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the input object that is used in a pipeline command.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the name of a driver. This cmdlet removes the ODBC DSN that uses the driver that this parameter specifies. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet removes DSNs for all drivers.
Specifies the type of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet removes DSNs of the type that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- User
- System
- All
Specifies the input object that is used in a pipeline command.
Specifies the name of an ODBC DSNs. You can use wildcard characters to specify more than one name. This cmdlet removes the DSNs that the names specify.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet removes the ODBC DSNs that belong to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove 32-bit User DSNs that have names that contain a string

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the 32-bit ODBC User DSNs that have names that contain Payroll.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Remove the System DSN named MyPayroll from the native platform

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the ODBC System DSN named MyPayroll from the native platform.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Remove all 32-bit ODBC System DSNs by using wildcard characters

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes all 32-bit ODBC System DSNs that have names that contain the string Payroll , and use the driver that has a name that starts with SQL Server.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 4: Remove a 32-bit ODBC User DSN by using a name ---

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the 32-bit ODBC User DSNs named MyPayroll, and then stores the deleted DSN object in the $SysDsn variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Remove a System DSN on the native platform by using the pipeline operator

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses the Get-OdbcDsn to get the ODBC System DSN on the native platform named MyPayroll, and then passes it to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The example removes that DSN.

command:example.maml:title: Example 6: Remove a ODBC System DSN on the native platform by using a variable
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $DsnArray = Get-OdbcDsn -Name "MyPayroll" -DsnType "System" PS C:\> Remove-OdbcDsn -InputObject $DsnArray

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command uses Get-OdbcDsn to get the ODBC System DSN on the native platform named MyPayroll, and then stores it in the $DsnArray variable.
The second command removes the DSN stored in $DsnArray.

maml:description.maml:para: Configures properties for existing ODBC DSNs.

The Set-OdbcDsn cmdlet configures the properties for existing Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) data source names (DSNs). Specify properties to add or modify by using the SetPropertyValue parameter. Specify properties to remove by using the RemovePropertyValue parameter.
Use the Add-OdbcDsn cmdlet to add a new DSN.

For more information about ODBC, data source names, and drivers, see Microsoft Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms710252.aspx), [Data Sources](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms711688.aspx), and [Drivers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms715383.aspx)on the Microsoft Developer Network.
Specifies the name of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet modifies the DSN that this parameter specifies. You can use wildcard characters to specify more than one ODBC DSN.
Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the name of a driver. This cmdlet modifies the ODBC DSN that uses the driver that this parameter specifies. You can use wildcard characters. If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet modifies DSNs for all drivers.
Specifies the type of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet modifies a DSN of the type that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- User
- System
- All
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the platform architecture. This cmdlet modifies the ODBC DSN that belongs to the architecture that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- 32-bit
- 64-bit
- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.
Specifies an array of property values to remove. This cmdlet removes the property values that this parameter specifies from the ODBC DSN. Specify an array of keys to remove.
Specifies an array of property values. This cmdlet modifies the properties that this parameter specifies for the ODBC DSN. Specify array of strings of the form <key>=<value>.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete.

The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies an array of property values to remove. This cmdlet removes the property values that this parameter specifies from the ODBC DSN. Specify an array of keys to remove.
Specifies an array of property values. This cmdlet modifies the properties that this parameter specifies for the ODBC DSN. Specify array of strings of the form <key>=<value>.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The default is the current session on the local computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the type of an ODBC DSN. This cmdlet modifies a DSN of the type that this parameter specifies. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
- User
- System
- All

- 32-bit

- All

The default value is 32-bit on a 32-bit process. The default value is 64-bit on a 64-bit process. If you run this cmdlet in a remote CIM session, this parameter refers to the platform architecture on the remote computer.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Change a 64-bit ODBC DSN to use a specified database

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the 64-bit ODBC System DSN named MyPayroll to use a database named Payroll. This example is designed for SQL Server drivers.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Change a native platform ODBC DSN to use a specified database

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the native platform ODBC System DSN named MyPayroll to use a database named Payroll. This example resembles the previous example, but it does not specify the Platform parameter.Therefore, configures a DSN on the native platform.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Change a User DSN to use Windows Authentication and a specified database

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the specified 32-bit ODBC User DSN named MyPayroll from using SQL Server Authentication to using Windows Authentication. This example is designed for SQL Server drivers. Also, the command specifies a value of Payroll for the Database key.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Change specified DSNs to use a specified database file

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes all ODBC User DSNs and System DSNs on both platforms with names that contain Payroll and that use a driver named Microsoft Access Driver ( .mdb, .accdb) to use the database file C:\payroll.accdb.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Migrate all DSNs that use a driver with name that starts with a string
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-OdbcDsn -DriverName "SQL Server*" -DsnType "All" -Platform "All" | Where-Object{ ($_.Attribute["Server"] -eq "oldServer") } | Set-OdbcDsn -SetPropertyValue "Server=newServer"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command migrates the oldServer to newServer for all User DSNs and System DSNs that use a driver that has a name that starts with SQL Server.

command:example.maml:title: Example 6: Change a 64-bit ODBC System DSN to use a specified database

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the 64-bit ODBC System DSN named MyPayroll to use a database named Payroll, and then stores the result in the $sysDsn variable. The command includes the PassThru parameter. Without PassThru , the cmdlet does not return anything.

command:example.maml:title: Example 7: Migrates DSNs that use a driver with name that starts with a string by using a variable
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $DsnArray = Get-OdbcDsn -DriverName "SQL Server*" | Where-Object{ ($_.Attribute["Server"] -eq "oldServer") } PS C:\> Set-OdbcDsn -InputObject $DsnArray -SetPropertyValue "Server=newServer"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command uses the Get-OdbcDsn cmdlet to get each driver that has a name that starts with SQL Server and has a value of oldServer for the Server attribute. The command stores the results in the $DsnArray variable.
The second command sets the value for Server to a new value.
